title: Starry Night
description: Starry Night is one of Vincent van Gogh's most famous paintings. It was painted in June 1889 and depicts the view from the east-facing window of his asylum room at Saint-Rémy-de-Provence, just before sunrise.

title: The Persistence of Memory
description: The Persistence of Memory is a painting by artist Salvador Dalí, and is one of his most recognizable works. It is known for the melting clocks and is thought to be a representation of the relativity of space and time.

title: David
description: David is a masterpiece of Renaissance sculpture created between 1501 and 1504 by the Italian artist Michelangelo. It is a 5.17-metre (17.0 ft) marble statue of the Biblical hero David, a favoured subject in the art of Florence.

title: Mona Lisa
description: The Mona Lisa is a half-length portrait painting by the Italian artist Leonardo da Vinci. It is considered an archetypal masterpiece of the Italian Renaissance, and has been described as 'the best known, the most visited, the most written about, the most sung about, the most parodied work of art in the world.'

title: The Thinker
description: The Thinker is a bronze sculpture by Auguste Rodin, usually placed on a stone pedestal. It depicts a man in sober meditation battling with a powerful internal struggle. The unique original plaster was exhibited in 1888 and numerous versions were placed all over the world.

title: Guernica
description: Guernica is one of Pablo Picasso's most famous works. This large mural-sized oil painting on canvas was created in 1937 and reflects the artist's horror at the Nazi German bombing of Guernica, Spain, during the Spanish Civil War. The monochromatic artwork speaks to the anguish, devastation, and chaos caused by the event, embodying an overall anti-war message.

title: Water Lilies
description: Water Lilies is a series of approximately 250 oil paintings by French Impressionist Claude Monet. The paintings depict Monet's flower garden at his home in Giverny and are some of his most famous works. He began the series during the last 30 years of his life, utilizing a distinct, abstract technique and vibrant colors to capture the beauty of the natural scene.

title: Jimson Weed/White Flower No. 1
description: Jimson Weed/White Flower No. 1 is an iconic painting by American artist Georgia O’Keeffe. Created in 1932, the artwork depicts a close-up view of a white jimson weed flower. O’Keeffe’s ability to beautifully capture the essence and intricacies of the flower demonstrates her attention to detail and her appreciation for the natural world.

title: The Two Fridas
description: The Two Fridas is an iconic painting created by Frida Kahlo in 1939. It is a double self-portrait, depicting two versions of Kahlo seated together. The two figures are connected by both hands and by a heart that is open to the viewer. The work speaks to Kahlo's experiences and emotions, particularly in relation to her turbulent relationship with fellow artist Diego Rivera.

title: Number 1A, 1948
description: Number 1A, 1948 is a classic example of Jackson Pollock's 'drip' technique, which he began using in 1947. Instead of using a brush, Pollock would let paint drip from a can onto the canvas, which was laid out on the ground. Pollock allowed the paint to land as it may, often not touching the canvas at all, which created a chaotic yet controlled and intricate network of lines.
